channel.title: Where did you learn your language?
channel.description: What source did you use to learn your primary scripting/programming language. Comment link and language? The point of this is me learning to use more than just java and python, I feel like an idiot.

I learned English in school. English is the only language I’ve learned.

item.title: Where did you learn your language?
item.dc:creator: @ranger_squad ranger squad
item.description:
@ranger_squad wrote:

I was looking for a way to level up quickly on RuneScape and I found out about “Xeath-PK” and I was told to go to www.moparisthebest.com. I played this for a while and then registered on moparisthebest.com, thinking it was the xeath-pk forums. I lurked for a bit before I found out the actual meaning of the forums and then I set up a small server. I wanted more and more control over what happened in my server and so I learnt the language by myself.

Read full topic

item.source: Where did you learn your language?

item.title: Where did you learn your language?
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

I started with C++ way back in the day developing on what I believe was Visual C++ 6 with my cousin. His dad knew C++ and occasionally helped us out. Later I got into Game Maker, which helped me with game stuff, and then found RSPS. Here is where I got into writing working code and working with other sources. I never read a single tutorial, but rather just looked at other code and was able to piece together what did what.

Then I found Visual Basic 6 and stuck to that for a long time because that’s what ROM hacking tools were generally written in. I figured most of the stuff out on my own, and like before, looked at other code. Eventually I moved onto Visual Basic .NET, but because of it being harder, I stuck with VB6 and it wasn’t for a while that I actually decided to move up. Here is where I started getting into what I currently do now, which is designing windows, creating controls, doing other drawing stuff, making text editing applications, etc…

One day I decided to download Visual C# 2005 and randomly opened it and started writing code. I figured most of it out based on the intellisense, error correction, and what knowledge I had from VB .NET. For no real reason at all I stuck with it and here I am today.

Read full topic
item.source: Where did you learn your language?

item.title: Where did you learn your language?
item.dc:creator: @Ruby_Forums_Coder Ruby
item.description:
@Ruby_Forums_Coder wrote:

I learned my web designing stuff from all over the web, just googling tutorials really.

I learned a of my limited java knowledge from http://www.homeandlearn.co.uk/java/java.html
and most of my beginnings of php from http://www.homeandlearn.co.uk/php/php.html

After learning the basics, I just built on top of those building my own programs and screwing around, experimenting if you will.

Read full topic

item.title: Where did you learn your language?
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

If you want to learn web development languages, there are tutorials everywhere.

For most of the languages I’ve learned, I’ve just followed complete tutorials then experimented. By experimenting I mean programming random things and fixing the errors.

Seriously though, google is great.
